description: A broad introduction to Mathematical Logic. The notions of logical consequence and derivation are introduced in the settings of propositional and first order logic, with discussions of the completeness theorem and satisfiability.
title: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
prerequisites: (MATH 225/126 and CS 116/136/145) or MATH 235 or 245; Not open to Computer Science students.
notes: [Note: PMATH 432 may be substituted for PMATH 330 whenever the latter is a requirement in an Honours plan.]
subject: PMATH

description: Topology of Euclidean spaces, continuity, norms, completeness. Contraction mapping principle. Fourier series. Various applications, for example, to ordinary differential equations, optimization and numerical approximation.
title: Applied Real Analysis
prerequisites: MATH 237 or 247; Not open to General Mathematics students
notes: [Note: PMATH 351 may be substituted for AMATH/PMATH 331 whenever the latter is a requirement in an Honours plan]
subject: PMATH

description: Complex numbers, Cauchy-Riemann equations, analytic functions, conformal maps and applications to the solution of Laplace's equation, contour integrals, Cauchy integral formula, Taylor and Laurent expansions, residue calculus and applications.
title: Applied Complex Analysis
prerequisites: MATH 237 or 247; Not open to General Mathematics students.
notes: [Note: PMATH 352 may be substituted for AMATH/PMATH 332 whenever the latter is a requirement in an Honours plan.]
subject: PMATH

description: Rings, ideals, factor rings, homomorphisms, finite and infinite fields, polynomials and roots, field extensions, algebraic numbers, and applications, for example, to Latin squares, finite geometries, geometrical constructions, error-correcting codes.
title: Introduction to Rings and Fields with Applications
prerequisites: MATH 235 or 245; Not open to General Mathematics students
notes: [Note: PMATH 345 may be substituted for PMATH 334 whenever the latter is a requirement in an Honours plan.]
subject: PMATH

description: Groups, permutation groups, subgroups, homomorphisms, symmetry groups in 2 and 3 dimensions, direct products, Polya-Burnside enumeration.
title: Introduction to Group Theory with Applications
prerequisites: MATH 235 or 245; Not open to General Mathematics students
notes: [Note: PMATH 346 may be substituted for PMATH 336 whenever the latter is a requirement in an Honours plan.]
subject: PMATH

description: An elementary approach to the theory of numbers; the Euclidean algorithm, congruence equations, multiplicative functions, solutions to Diophantine equations, continued fractions, and rational approximations to real numbers.
title: Elementary Number Theory
notes: [Note: PMATH 440 may be substituted for PMATH 340 whenever the latter is a requirement in an Honours plan.]
subject: PMATH

description: Elementary properties of rings, polynomial rings, Gaussian integers, integral domains and fields of fractions, homomorphisms and ideals, maximal ideals and fields, Euclidean rings, principal ideals, Hilbert Basis theorem, Gauss' lemma, Eisenstein's criterion, unique factorization, computational aspects of polynomials, construction of finite fields with applications, primitive roots and polynomials, additional topics. [Offered: F,S]
title: Polynomials, Rings and Finite Fields
prerequisites: MATH 235 or 245; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Elementary properties of groups, cyclic groups, permutation groups, Lagrange's theorem, normal subgroups, homomorphisms, isomorphism theorems and automorphisms, Cayley's theorem and generalizations, class equation, combinatorial applications, p-groups, Sylow theorems, groups of small order, simplicity of the alternating groups, direct product, fundamental structure theorem for finitely generated Abelian groups.
title: Group Theory
prerequisites: MATH 235 or 245; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Groups, subgroups, homomorphisms and quotient groups, isomorphism theorems, group actions, Cayley and Lagrange theorems, permutation groups and the fundamental theorem of finite abelian groups. Elementary properties of rings, subrings, ideals, homomorphisms and quotients, isomorphism theorems, polynomial rings, and unique factorization domains.
title: Groups and Rings
prerequisites: MATH 235 or 245; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Fields, algebraic and transcendental extensions, minimal polynomials, Eisenstein's criterion, splitting fields, and the structure of finite fields. Sylow theorems and solvable groups. Galois theory. The insolvability of the quintic.
title: Fields and Galois Theory
prerequisites: PMATH 347; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Normed and metric spaces, open sets, continuous mappings, sequence and function spaces, completeness, contraction mappings, compactness of metric spaces, finite-dimensional normed spaces, Arzela-Ascoli theorem, existence of solutions of differential equations, Stone-Weierstrass theorem.
title: Real Analysis
prerequisites: MATH 247 or PMATH 352; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations, Goursat's theorem, Cauchy's theorems, Morera's theorem, Liouville's theorem, maximum modulus principle, harmonic functions, Schwarz's lemma, isolated singularities, Laurent series, residue theorem.
title: Complex Analysis
prerequisites: MATH 237 or 247 or AMATH/PMATH 331; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Lebesgue measure on the line, the Lebesgue integral, monotone and dominated convergence theorems, Lp-spaces: completeness and dense subspaces. Separable Hilbert space, orthonormal bases. Fourier analysis on the circle, Dirichlet kernel, Riemann-Lebesgue lemma, Fejer's theorem and convergence of Fourier series. [Offered: W]
title: Measure Theory and Fourier Analysis
prerequisites: PMATH 351; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to affine, projective and non-Euclidean forms of geometry. Conic sections in the projective plane. Inversion in circles. Theorems of Desargues, Pappus, and Pascal.
title: Geometry
prerequisites: MATH 225/126 or MATH 235 or 245.
notes: [Note: This course will be of interest to all math students.]
subject: PMATH

description:
An introduction to local differential geometry, laying the groundwork
for both global differential geometry and general relativity.
Submanifolds of n-dimensional Euclidean space. Embedded curves and
the intrinsic geometry of surfaces in Euclidean 3-space. Metrics,
geodesics, and curvature. Gaussian curvature and the Gauss-Bonnet
theorem. [Offered: W]
title: Elementary Differential Geometry
prerequisites: (AMATH 231 or MATH 247) and MATH 235 or 245; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Relations, functions, well-orderings, Schroder-Bernstein theorem, recursion, axiom of choice and equivalents, ordinals, cardinals, continuum hypothesis, singular and inaccessible cardinals. Topological spaces, bases and sub-bases, closure and interior, product spaces, quotient spaces, nets and filters. Hausdorff spaces, completely regular and normal spaces, Urysohn's lemma, Tietze extension theorum. Compactness, Tychonoff's theorum, Stone-Cech compactification. Connectedness, path connectedness, Function spaces.
title: Set Theory & General Topology
prerequisites: AMATH/PMATH 331 or PMATH 351; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: The mathematics of iterated functions, properties of discrete dynamical systems, Mandelbrot and Julia sets.
title: Chaos and Fractals
prerequisites: (One of MATH 118, 119, 128, 138, 148) and (One of MATH 114, 115, 225/126, 235, 245); Not open to General Mathematics students
notes: [Note: Programming experience on one computer language with graphical output is recommended.]
subject: PMATH

title: Readings in Pure Mathematics
prerequisites: Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: The concepts of formal provability and logical consequence in first order logic are introduced, and their equivalence is proved in the soundness and completeness theorems. Goedel's incompleteness theorem is discussed, making use of the halting problem of computability theory. Relative computability and the Turing degrees are further studied.
title: First Order Logic and Computability
prerequisites: PMATH 345 or 346 or 347; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Model theory: the semantics of first order logic including the compactness theorem and its consequences, elementary embeddings and equivalence, the theory of definable sets and types, quantifier elimination, and omega-stability. Set theory: well-orderings, ordinals, cardinals, Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms, axiom of choice, informal discussion of classes and independence results.
title: Model Theory and Set Theory
prerequisites: PMATH 345 or 346 or 347; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to: integer factorization, elliptic curves methods, primality testing, fast integer arithmetic, fast Fourier transforms and quantum computing. This course is taught with a philosophy that encourages experimentation.
title: Techniques in Computational Number Theory
prerequisites: One of CM 339/CS 341, PMATH 334, 336, 345, 346; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to elementary and analytic number theory; primitive roots, law of quadratic reciprocity, Gaussian sums, Riemann zeta-function, distribution of prime numbers.
title: Analytic Number Theory
prerequisites: PMATH 352 or AMATH/PMATH 332; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to algebraic number theory; unique factorization, Dedekind domains, class numbers, Dirichlet's unit theorem, solutions of Diophantine equations, Fermat's "last theorem".
title: Algebraic Number Theory
prerequisites: PMATH 345 or 348; Not open to General Mathematics students.
subject: PMATH

description: Normal series, elementary properties of solvable groups and simple groups, algebraic and transcendental extensions of fields, adjoining roots, splitting fields, geometric constructions, separability, normal extensions, Galois groups, fundamental theorem of Galois theory, solvability by radicals, Galois groups of equations, cyclotomic and Kummer extensions.
title: Fields and Galois Theory
prerequisites: PMATH 345, 346; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Jacobson structure theory, density theorem, Jacobson radical, Maschke's theorem. Artinian rings, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, modules over semi-simple Artinian rings. Division rings. Representations of finite groups.
title: Rings, Modules, and Representations
prerequisites: PMATH 345; Not open to General Mathematics students.
subject: PMATH

description: Basic definitions and examples: subrepresentations and irreducible representations, tensor products of representations. Character theory. Representations as modules over the group ring, Artin-Wedderburn structure theorem for semisimple rings. Induced representations, Frobenius reciprocity, Mackey's irreducibility criterion
title: Representations of Finite Groups
prerequisites: (PMATH 345 and 346) or 347; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Module theory: classification of finitely generated modules over PIDs, exact sequences and tensor products, algebras, localisation, chain conditions. Primary decomposition
title: Introduction to Commutative Algebra
prerequisites: PMATH 345 or 347; Not open to General Mathematics students.
subject: PMATH

description: Lebesgue measure on the line, the Lebesgue integral, monotone and dominated convergence theorems, Lp-spaces: completeness and dense subspaces. Separable Hilbert space, orthonormal bases. Fourier analysis on the circle, Dirichlet kernel, Riemann-Lebesgue lemma, Fejer's theorem and convergence of Fourier series.
title: Lebesgue Integration and Fourier Analysis
prerequisites: PMATH 351 with a grade of at least of 60%; Not open to General Mathematics students.
subject: PMATH

description: General measures, measurability, Caratheodory Extension theorem and construction of measures, integration theory, convergence theorems, Lp-spaces, absolute continuity, differentiation of monotone functions, Radon-Nikodym theorem, product measures, Fubini's theorem, signed measures, Urysohn's lemma, Riesz Representation theorems for classical Banach spaces.
title: Measure and Integration
prerequisites: PMATH 354/450 with a grade of at least 60%; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: Banach and Hilbert spaces, bounded linear maps, Hahn-Banach theorem, open mapping theorem, closed graph theorem, topologies, nets, Hausdorff spaces, Tietze extension theorem, dual spaces, weak topologies, Tychonoff's theorem, Banach-Alaoglu theorem, reflexive spaces.
title: Functional Analysis
prerequisites: PMATH 354/450; Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description:
An introduction to algebraic geometry through the theory of algebraic
curves. General Algebraic Geometry: affine and projective algebraic sets,
Hilbert's Nullstellensatz, co-ordinate rings, polynomial maps, rational
functions and local rings. Algebraic Curves: affine and projective plane
curves, tangency and multiplicity, intersection numbers, Bezout's theorem
and divisor class groups.
title: Introduction to Algebraic Geometry
prerequisites: PMATH 345 or 347; Not open to General Mathematics students.
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to differentiable manifolds. The tangent and cotangent bundles. Vector fields and differential forms. The Lie bracket and Lie derivative of vector fields. Exterior differentiation, integration of differential forms, and Stokes's Theorem. Riemannian manifolds, affine connections, and the Riemann curvature tensor.
title: Differential Geometry
prerequisites: AMATH 333/PMATH 365; Not open to General Mathematics students
notes: [Note: Offered in the Winter of even years.]
subject: PMATH

description: Review of general topology, quotient spaces, scissors and glue constructions. Basics on homotopy and topological manifolds. The fundamental group. Compact surfaces. Introduction to homology. Selected applications to covering spaces, homotopy theory, general manifolds, knots, differential equation, combinatorial group theory.
title: Topology
prerequisites: PMATH 351 or 367; Not open to General Mathematics students.
subject: PMATH

title: Readings in Pure Mathematics
prerequisites: Not open to General Mathematics students
subject: PMATH

description: The concepts of formal provability and logical consequence in first order logic are introduced, and their equivalence is proved in the soundness and completeness theorems.  Goedel's incompleteness theorem is discussed; making use of the halting problem of computability theory.  Relative computability and the Turing degrees are further studied.
title: First Order Logic and Computability
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 345 or 346 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to algebraic number theory; unique factorization, Dedekind domains, class numbers, Dirichlet's unit theorem, solutions of Diophantine equations, Fermat's last theorem. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Algebraic Number Theory
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 345 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: Normal series, elementary properties of solvable groups and simple groups, algebraic and transcendental extensions of fields, adjoining roots, splitting fields, geometric constructions, separability, normal extensions, Galois groups, fundamental theorem of Galois theory, solvability by radicals, Galois groups of equations, cyclotomic and Kummer extensions. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Fields and Galois Theory
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PMATH 345 and 346 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: Jacobson structure theory, density theorem, Jacobson radical, Maschke's theorem.  Artinian rings, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, modules over semi-simple Artinian rings.  Division rings.  Representations of finite groups.  Finitely generated modules over principal ideal domains.   Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Rings, Modules and Representations
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PMATH 345 and 346 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: Module theory:  classification of finitely generated modules over PIDs, exact sequences and tensor products, algebras, localisation, chain conditions.  Primary decomposition, integral extensions, Noether's normalisation lemma, and Hilbert's Nullstellensatz.
title: Introduction to Commutative Algebra
prerequisites: PMATH 347, 348
subject: PMATH

description: Lebesgue measure on the line, the Lebesgue integral, monotone and dominated convergence theorems, Lp-spaces, completeness and dense subspaces.  Separable Hilbert space, orthonormal bases.  Fourier analysis on the circle, Dirichlet kernel, Riemann-Lebesgue lemma, Fejer's theorem and convergence of Fourier series.
title: Lebesgue Integration and Fourier Analysis
prerequisites: PMATH 351
subject: PMATH

description: General measures, measurability, Caratheodory Extension theorem and construction of measures, integration theory, convergence theorems, Lp-spaces, absolute continuity, differentiation of monotone functions, Radon-Nikodym theorem, product measures, Fubini's theorem, signed measures, Urysohn's lemma, Riesz Representation theorems for classical Banach spaces. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Measure and Integration
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 354/450 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: The Riemann mapping theorem and several topics such as analytic continuation, harmonic functions, elliptic functions, entire functions, univalent functions, special functions. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Topics in Complex Analysis
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 352 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: Some global aspects of surface theory, the Euler-Poincar characteristic, the global interpretation of Gaussian curvature via the Gauss-Bonnet formula. Submanifolds of n-space, induced Riemannian metrics, extrinsic and intrinsic curvatures, Gauss-Codazzi equations. Local Lie groups of transformations on n-space, infinitesimal generators, the Lie derivative. An introduction to differentiable manifolds, the tangent and cotangent bundels, affine connections and the Riemann curavture tensor. The above topics will be illustrated by applications to continuum mechanics and mathematical physics. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Differential Geometry
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PMATH 365 or  AM 333 or consent of Department
subject: PMATH

description: Topics from algebraic, combinatorial and geometric topology. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Topology
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 351 or consent of Department
subject: PMATH

description: Reading Course
title: Literature and Research Studies
subject: PMATH

description: Isomorphism theorems, classical structures theorems for finite groups, nilpotent and solvable groups, free groups, presentation modules over Principal Ideal Domains (PIDs), Hilbert Basis Theorem, Groebner bases, Artin-Wedderbury Theorem, field extensions, decompositions, claculation of Galois groups.
title: Graduate Algebra
subject: PMATH

description: Zorn's Lemma and the Axiom of Choice, cardinality, introduction to topological spaces, bases, nets, continuous functions and weak topologies, compactness, connectedness, Banach spaces, Contraction Mapping Principal, finite-dimensional spaces C(X) and C_O(X), Stone-Weierstrass Theorem, Arzela-Ascoli Theorem, Urysohn's Lemma, idelas in C_O(X).
title: Graduate Analysis
subject: PMATH

description: Model theory:  the semantics of first order logic including the compactness theorem and its consequences, elementary embedding and equivalence, the theory of definable sets and types, quantifier elimination, and w-stability.  Set theory:  well-orderings, ordinals, cardinals, Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms, axiom of choice, informal discussion of classes and indpendence results.
title: Model Theory and Set Theory
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to elementary and analytic number theory; primitive roots, law of quadratic reciporcity, Gaussian sums, Riemann zeta-function, distribution of prime numbers. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the department.
title: Analytic Number Theory
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 332 or 352 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: Techniques for classification of finite groups: p-groups, Sylow Theorems, direct and semidirect products.  Representations of finite groups: character theory, restrictions and tensor products of representations, representations as modules over group algebras, induced representations, Frobenius reciprocity, Mackey's irreducibility criterion.
title: Groups and Representations
prerequisites: PMATH 347
subject: PMATH

description: Banach and Hilvert spaces, bounded linear maps, Hahn-Banach theorem, open mapping theorem, closed graph theorem, topologies, nets, Hausdorff spaces, Tietze extension theorem, dual spaces, weak topologies, Tychonoff's theorem, Banach-Alaoglu theorem, reflexive spaces.
title: Functional Analysis
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 354/450 or consent of department.
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to matrix Lie groups and their associated Lie algebra's: geometry of matrix Lie groups; relations between a matrix Lie group and its Lie algebra; representation theory of matrix Lie groups.
title: Introduction to Lie Groups and Lie Algebras
prerequisites: Prerequisite:  PMATH 346, 351 and 365
subject: PMATH

description: An introduction to the geometry of algebraic curves with applications to elliptic curves and computational algebraic geometry. Plane curves, affine varieties, the group law on the cubic, and applications.
title: Algebraic Curves
subject: PMATH

title: Topics in Real and Complex Analysis
subject: PMATH

description: Banach algebras, functional calculus, Gelfan transform, Jacobson radical, Banach space and Hilbert space operators, Fredholm alternative, spectral therorem for compact normal operators, ideals in C^*-algebras, linear functionals and states, Gelfand-Naimark-Segar (GNS) construction, von Neumann algebras, strong/weak operator topologies, Double Commutant theorem, Kaplansky's Density Theorem, spectral theorem for normal operators.
title: Banach Algebras and Operator Theory
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PMATH 653
subject: PMATH
